channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘She. Herself. Naked.’: The Art of He Chengyao
item.description: Her birth brought her mother punishment. Since then He Chengyao has spoken out artististically for a woman whose life was haunted by mental illness, in mother-daughter inspired works that involve a lot of nudity. For a reason.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Shanghai Doctor Dies of Bird Flu
item.description: Investigators are trying to determine if the doctor had contact with poultry or live birds, as in most previous H7N9 cases, or if he might have contracted the disease from a patient.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Health officials collecting geese at a poultry market in Zhuji, Zhejiang Province. The local government ordered all live poultry killed at two markets in Zhuji as a preventive measure against the H7N9 avian flu.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, a Week Full of Trials Over Dissent
item.description: At least seven citizens are due to stand trial for participating in the New Citizens Movement and other protest groups.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: India Ink: For Aam Aadmi Interns, Politics Involves Paperwork and Occasional Screaming Protest
item.description: The promise of a good internship experience has drawn over 200 students to the party’s Mumbai chapter since November.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI
item.media:description: Volunteers gather at an Aam Aadmi Party office in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Jan. 14.

item.title: Police and Protesters in Ukraine Escalate Use of Force
item.description: Protests in Kiev took a darker turn as the riot police unleashed stun grenades and rubber bullets, and protesters built a catapult and threw firebombs.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A man sprayed fire toward riot police officers in Kiev, Ukraine, on Monday as protests that have been going on for over two months grew more confrontational.

item.title: Japan Defends Dolphin Hunt After Kennedy Criticism
item.description: A Japanese official defended dolphin fishing as a tradition after Ambassador Caroline Kennedy took issue with the “drive hunt,” in which dolphins are herded into an area from where they cannot escape.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Talks Over Syria Are Set to Begin, but Iran Is Not Invited
item.description: Diplomats managed to salvage the talks, which had seemed on the verge of unraveling after the United Nations secretary general invited Iran to attend.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A hotel in Montreux, Switzerland, was ready for talks on Syria.

item.title: Hollande’s Romances Turn Into a Political Spectacle in France
item.description: François Hollande once vowed to be on his most exemplary behavior as president of France. But an affair has exposed a more politically calculating side and threatens to undercut his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: François Hollande’s love life is testing France’s tolerance.

item.title: Failed Talks With Militants Prompt Many to Flee in Iraq
item.description: A tentative agreement to allow officials to return to Falluja fell apart after jihadist militants kidnapped local negotiators, those involved in the talks said.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and YASIR GHAZI
item.media:description: The site of a car bomb attack in the town of Tuz Khurmatu, north of Baghdad, on Monday.

item.title: Cards From Target Breach Being Sold in Custom Sets, Police Say
item.description: Police say the stolen cards held by two Mexican citizens arrested at the border in Texas suggest that the data is available in regionally tailored batches.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: U.S. Plans Naval Backup for Olympics
item.description: Two Navy warships will be in the Black Sea during the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, next month, should they be needed to evacuate Americans, a Pentagon official said.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Prison Escapee Vows to Fight Again
item.description: Christodoulos Xiros, a leftist guerrilla who walked away from prison while on furlough this month, on Monday announced his return to terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: New Leak Detected at Crippled Reactor
item.description: Highly radioactive water found in a reactor building at the Fukushima nuclear plant indicates that the reactor’s containment vessel was breached during the accident, the plant’s operator said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: 14 Companies Bid to Destroy Chemical Weapons
item.description: The companies, including four from the United States, have bid for contracts to eradicate 500 tons of chemicals in Syria’s munitions stockpile.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: Government Forces Claim to Recapture Regional Capital
item.description: The government said on Monday that it had regained control of Malakal, the capital of the oil-producing Upper Nile state.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Theft of Data Fuels Worries in South Korea
item.description: A string of senior executives at three credit card companies offered to resign on Monday after a huge theft of client data may have affected 20 million people.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Claudio Abbado, an Italian Conductor With a Global Reach, Is Dead at 80
item.description: Mr. Abbado led some of the world’s most revered musical institutions, including La Scala, the Vienna State Opera and the Berlin Philharmonic.
item.dc:creator: By ALLAN KOZINN

item.title: A Popular Chinese Social Networking App Blazes Its Own Path
item.description: Weixin, a fast-growing app from the Chinese Internet company Tencent, is no mere copy of any existing service, and its success may thwart Facebook’s ambitions in China.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Allen Zhang organized the team in Guangzhou that began in 2010 to develop the Weixin app for the Internet company Tencent.

item.title: The Lede: War Crimes Experts Call Syrian Defector’s Photographs ‘Direct Evidence’ of Assad’s ‘Killing Machine’
item.description: A team of legal and forensic experts concluded that post-mortem photographs, provided to the Syrian opposition by a man who describes himself as a defector from President Bashar al-Assad’s security forces, offer “direct evidence” of torture and execution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Jalazoun Refugee Camp Journal: U.N. Dispute Brings West Bank Differences to the Fore
item.description: Amid a United Nations strike that has brought food aid and education to a standstill, West Bank refugees are calling on the Palestinian Authority to take responsibility for their welfare.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the exception of a vaccination program for children, medical services at the Jalazoun refugee camp are at a standstill.

item.title: Delhi’s Leader Holds Protest Over Police
item.description: To protest police corruption, Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s chief minister, and supporters held a demonstration that shut down the heart of downtown.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, center, the chief minister of New Delhi, who was elected last month, said he was seeking justice for women.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,292 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Temporary Nuclear Deal With Iran Takes Effect
item.description: In return for curbing its enrichment of uranium, Iran is hoping that the economic benefits flow in after international sanctions are eased.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency and Iranian technicians at Natanz.

item.title: Woman Chosen to Lead Central African Republic Out of Mayhem
item.description: Catherine Samba-Panza, the mayor of Bangui, the capital, was elected by the makeshift Parliament to help end the bloodshed and hold elections.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Catherine Samba-Panza after her election on Monday in Bangui, Central African Republic.

item.title: China Exports Pollution to U.S., Study Finds
item.description: Emissions from China’s export industries are carried across the Pacific and contribute to air pollution in the Western United States, according to a paper.
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Smog enveloping Beijing last summer. A group of researchers found that trans-Pacific air pollution is a hidden price of the goods sent abroad from China.
